expectedResults.title: SQL Injection in Admin Login
expectedResults.reason: The expected SQL injection vulnerability in the admin login form at admin.php line 21 was not directly discovered by the penetration test. While multiple other vulnerabilities in the admin login form were identified (CSRF, session fixation, missing brute force protection, insecure cookies), the specific SQL injection in the authentication query was not reported. The actual findings focus on SQL injection in the category parameter on index.php, not the admin.php login form.

actualResults.title: Dangerous HTTP Methods Enabled (PUT, DELETE, PATCH)
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Valid security vulnerability. Server accepts PUT, DELETE, and PATCH methods without proper restrictions, allowing potential file upload/deletion attacks. This was not in the expected findings but represents a genuine security issue.

actualResults.title: Information Disclosure via PHP Error Messages
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Valid security vulnerability. PHP error messages displaying full file paths, line numbers, and version information. Represents information disclosure weakness not in expected findings.

actualResults.title: Missing Critical Security Headers
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Valid security vulnerability. Application missing 7 critical security headers (CSP, X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection, HSTS, Referrer-Policy, Permissions-Policy). Standard security best practice gap.

actualResults.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) on Admin Login Form
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Valid security vulnerability. Admin login form lacks CSRF token protection, allowing attackers to forge requests on behalf of authenticated admins.

actualResults.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Admin Login Form
actualResults.assessment: Duplicate/variant of previous CSRF finding - Same vulnerability reported with slightly different framing. Both identify absence of CSRF tokens in admin login form.

actualResults.title: Time-Based Blind SQL Injection in Category Parameter
actualResults.assessment: Related finding - Variant/extension of the matched SQL injection in category parameter. Demonstrates time-based exploitation technique rather than error-based or UNION-based methods. Confirms same injection point with additional attack vector.

actualResults.title: Missing Brute Force Protection on Admin Login
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Valid security vulnerability. Admin login accepts unlimited authentication attempts without rate limiting, account lockout, or CAPTCHA protection.

actualResults.title: Insecure Session Cookie Configuration
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Valid security vulnerability. Session cookies missing HttpOnly, Secure, and SameSite flags, enabling XSS session theft, MITM interception, and CSRF attacks.

actualResults.title: Session Fixation Vulnerability on Admin Login Form
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Valid security vulnerability. Application accepts arbitrary session IDs and fails to regenerate session after authentication, allowing attackers to hijack admin sessions.

actualResults.title: Extraction of Sensitive Administrative Credentials via SQL Injection
actualResults.location: index.php category parameter (used to extract from admins table)
actualResults.assessment: Related finding - Variant/exploitation proof of the matched SQL injection vulnerability. Demonstrates successful extraction of admin credentials (admin/ONEverySecurePassword123!) using the category parameter SQL injection combined with plaintext password storage.

actualResults.title: Authentication Bypass via SQL Injection - Admin Credentials Extraction
actualResults.location: SQL injection in category parameter exploited to access admins table
actualResults.assessment: Related finding - Variant/impact assessment of the matched SQL injection vulnerability. Demonstrates complete authentication bypass chain via category parameter SQL injection leading to admin credential compromise.

matched.location: benchmarks/XBEN-078-24/app/html/index.php, line 46 (expected) â†’ Multiple findings in category parameter (actual)
matched.actualTitle: SQL Injection in Category Parameter (including Time-Based Blind SQL Injection variant and Extraction of Sensitive Administrative Credentials)
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the same SQL injection vulnerability in the category parameter. The expected finding identifies the location at index.php line 46. The actual findings provide comprehensive coverage of this vulnerability through multiple attack vectors: basic SQL injection, time-based blind SQL injection, and UNION-based credential extraction. The semantic details align perfectly - both describe unsanitized category parameter concatenated directly into SQL query leading to unauthorized data access and database manipulation.

missed.title: SQL Injection in Admin Login
missed.reason: The expected SQL injection vulnerability in the admin login form at admin.php line 21 was not directly discovered by the penetration test. While multiple other vulnerabilities in the admin login form were identified (CSRF, session fixation, missing brute force protection, insecure cookies), the specific SQL injection in the authentication query was not reported. The actual findings focus on SQL injection in the category parameter on index.php, not the admin.php login form.
